рддреНрд╡ рдореЗ рдирд╛рдереЛ рдирд╛рдерд┐рддрдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдЦрд┐рд▓рдХрд╛рд░реА рдорд╛рдирд╛рддреАрддреЛ рдорд╛рдзрд╡рд░реВрдкреЛрд╜рдЦрд┐рд▓рдзрд╛рдЧреЗред
рднрдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдЧрдореНрдпреЛ рднрд╛рд╡рд┐рддрд░реВрдкреЛ рднрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реА рдпреЛрдЧрд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рд╕реИрд░реНрднрд╛рд╡рд┐рддрдЪреЗрдд, рд╕рд╣рдЪрд╛рд░реАрее…

(30) Bharadv─Бja tells R─Бma33^(1)тАФYou are the ultimate Brahman, free from the three conditions of beginning, middle and end You first created water and lay down in it. You are N─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa, the soul of the universe, the innermost soul of all human beings Brahm─Б, the creator of the universe was born from the lotus arising from your navel You are, therefore, the lord of the universe , you are Vis┼Жu, J─Бnaki is Laksm─лand Laksmaс╣Зa is ┼Ъesa (the N─Бga) You create all in yourself, through your own m─Бy─Б. You are not, however, attached to your creation, you are like the space, the witness to everything by virtue of your own citsukti You permeate the beings, both in and out You are complete in yourself and appear as divided only to those whose vision is distorted under the force of illusion You are the universe, you are the substratum of the universe and you are its sole preserverand support You are both the nourisher and nourishment of all beings You are all that is seen, heard and thought of All this exists when you are ignored but nothing of it exists when you are known

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

1.рддреНрд╡ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдо рдкрд░рдо рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рджрд╛рджрд┐рдордзреНрдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд╡рд░реНрдЬреНрдЬрд┐рддред
рддреНрд╡рдордЧреНрд░ рд╕рд▓рд┐рд▓ рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреНрд╡рд╛рддрддреНрд░рд╕реБрдкреНрддреЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рднреВрддрдХреГрддреНреерезренрее

рдирд╛рд░рд╛рдпрдгреЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд╛рддреНрдордиреН рдирд░рд╛рдгрд╛рдордиреНрддрд░рд╛рддреНрдордХред
рддреНрд╡рдиреНрдирд╛рднрд┐рдХрдорд▓реЛрддреНрдкрдиреНрдиреЛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛ рд▓реЛрдХрдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣реерезреорее

рдЕрддрд╕реНрддреНрд╡ рдЬрдЧрддрд╛рдореАрд╢ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд▓реЛрдХрдирдорд╕реНрдХреГрддред
рддреНрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБрд░реНрдЬрд╛рдирдХреА рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдореА. рд╢реЗрд╖реЛрд╜рдп рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдордгрд╛рднрд┐рдзреерезреорее

рдЖрддреНрдордирд╛ рд╕реГрдЬрд╕реАрдж рддреНрд╡рдорд╛рддреНрдордиреНрдпреЗрд╡рд╛рд╜рд╜рддреНрдордорд╛рдпрдпрд╛ред
рди рд╕рдЬреНрдЬрд╕реЗ рдирднреЛрд╡рддреНрддреНрд╡ рдЪрд┐рдЪреНрдЫрдХреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдХрдГреереирежрее

рдмрд╣рд┐рд░рдиреНрддрд╢реНрдЪ рднреВрддрд╛рдирд╛ рддреНрд╡рдореЗрд╡ рд░рдШреБрдирдиреНрджрдиред
рдкреВрд░реНрдгреЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рдореВрдврджреГрд╖реНрдЯреАрдирд╛ рд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрди рдЗрд╡рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╕реЗреереирезрее

рдЬрдЧрддреНрддреНрд╡ рдЬрдЧрджрд╛рдзрд╛рд░рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдореЗрд╡ рдкрд░рд┐рдкрд╛рд▓рдХред
рддреНрд╡рдореЗрд╡ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рднреВрддрд╛рдирд╛ рднреЛрдХреНрддрд╛ рднреЛрдЬреНрдп рдЬрдЧрддреНрдкрддреЗреереиреирее

рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рд╢реНрд░реВрдпрддреЗ рдпрджреН рдпрддреН рд╕реНрдорд░реНрдпрддреЗ рд╡рд╛ рд░рдШреВрддреНрддрдоред
рддреНрд╡рдореЗрд╡ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдордЦрд┐рд▓ рддреНрд╡рджреНрд╡рд┐рдирд╛рд╜рдиреНрдпрдиреНрдирдХрд┐рдЮреНрдЪрдиреереирейрее

A-R-4

The m─Бy─Б goaded on by you creates the world through its attributes ahamk─Бra and the like Just as immovable bolts or pins move in the proximity of the loadstone, cumbaka, so also m─Бy─Б, which, though inanimate, creates the world at your glance. Though you have no body, still, for the sake of the preservation of the world, you have two (illusory) bodies-gross and subtle. Thousands of incarnations emanate from the gross body and go back to it at the end of then work [VI 14 17-27]

(31) R─Б

ma, you are N─Бn─Бyaс╣Зa in person34┬╣тАУ the first creator of the universe. All this world, both animate and inanimate, is the same as yourself Brahm─Б, the creator of the world, is born from the lotus arising from your navel, Agni is born from your mouth along with speech, the Lokap─Бlas, from your hands, the sun and the moon, from your eyes, and, in fact, the various godsтАФ the two A┼Ыvins, Indra, Varuс╣Зa, the B─Бlakhilyas etc, arise from you you are the Vi┼Ыvar┼лpa, the Great Being endowed with the m─Бy─Б┼Ыakti.Youappeal under different forms through the connection of the gunas

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рд╕реГрдЬрддрд┐ рд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд╢реНрдЪ рд╕реНрд╡рдЧреБрдгреИрд░рд╣рдорд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐ред
рддреНрд╡рдЪреНрдЫрдХреНрддрд┐рдкреНрд░реЗрд░рд┐рддрд╛ рд░рд╛рдо рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреНрддреНрд╡рдпреНрдпреБрдкрдЪрд░реНрдпрддреЗреереирекрее

рдпрдерд╛ рдЪреБрдореНрдмрдХрд╕рд╛рдиреНрдирд┐рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд▓рдиреНрддреНрдпреЗ рд╡рд╛рдЪрд▓рд╛рджрдпред
рдЬрдбрд╛ рддрдерд╛ рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рд╕реГрдЬрддрд┐ рд╡реИрдЬрдЧрддреНреереирелрее

рджреЗрд╣рджреНрд╡рдпрдорджреЗрд╣рд╕реНрдпрддрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡ рд░рд┐рд░рдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╖реЛред
рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЯреН рд╕реНрдереВрд▓ рд╢рд░реАрд░ рддреЗ рд╕реВрддреНрд░ рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдордореБрджрд╛рд╣рддрдореереиремрее

рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЬ рд╕рдореНрднрд╡рдиреНрддреНрдпреЗрддреЗ рдЕрд╡рддрд╛рд░рд╛. рд╕рд╣рд╕реНрд░рд╢ред
рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрддреЗрдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢рдиреНрддреНрдпреЗрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЬ рд░рдШреБрдирдиреНрджрдиреереиренрее

1. рднрд╡рд╛рдиреНрдирд╛рд░рд╛рдпрдг рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд╛рдЬреНрдЬрдЧрддрд╛рдорд╛рджрд┐рдХреГрджреНрд╡рд┐рднреБред
рддреНрд╡рддреНрд╕реНрд╡рд░реВрдкрдорд┐рдж рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдЬрдЧрдд рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╡рд░рдЬрдЩреНрдЧрдордореНреерелрелрее

рддреНрд╡рдиреНрдирд╛рднрд┐рдХрдорд▓реЛрддрдкрдиреНрдиреЛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛ рд▓реЛрдХрдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣ред
рдЕрдЧреНрдирд┐рд╕реНрддреЗ рдореБрдЧреНрд╡рддреЛ рдЬрд╛рддреЛ рд╡рд╛рдЪрд╛ рд╕рд╣ рд░рдШреБрддреНрддрдореерелремрее

рдмрд╛рд╣реБрднреНрдпрд╛ рд▓реЛрдХрдкрд╛рд▓реМрдШрд╛рд╢реНрдЪрдХреНрд╖реБрд░реНрднреНрдпрд╛ рдЪрдиреНрджреНрд░рднрд╛рд╕реНрдХрд░реМред
рддреНрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд░реВрдк рдкреБрд░реБрд╖реЛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐рд╕рдордиреНрд╡рд┐рддред
рдирд╛рдирд╛рд░реВрдк рдЗрд╡рд╛рд╜рд╜рднрд╛рд╕рд┐ рдЧреБрдгрддреНрд░реНрдпрддрд┐рдХрд░реЗ рд╕рддрд┐рееремрезрее

The wise drink the ambrosia within by resigning themselves to you. You create the world, both animate and inanimate. The world lives for you and you are behind all things and acts, like the butterin milk which permeates it all through (but is not Visible). It is through your light that the sun shines and not that you shine through his light. The wise find you all-pervading and eternal the yogins see in you the lord within themselves [VII 2 55 ff]

(32) R─Бma is within and around all the worldHe sees

with his Vy├▒─Бna and he is the witness from within all, He is

ultimate, omnipresent and pureHe has taken the form of man

through l─лl─Бand the attributes of m─Бy─Б cannot touch him. His

is one endless and inconceivable power. He is consciousness alone, undecaying and unborn. He is the knower of the secret of ─Бtman35┬╣[VII 1 58-59]

(33) R─Бma took charge of the kingdom from Bharata36┬▓Thus the god acted like a common man through m─Бy─Б. He had thus the pleasure of possessing his own kingdom

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

рддреНрд╡рд╛рдорд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдпреИрд╡ рд╡рд┐рдмреБрдзрд╛ рдкрд┐рдмрдиреНрддреНрдпрдореГрддрдордзреНрд╡рд░реЗред
рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛ рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрдорд┐рдж рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡ рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╡рд░рдЬрдЩреНрдЧрдордореНрееремреирее

рддреНрд╡рд╛рдорд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдпреИрд╡ рдЬреАрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗ рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╡рд░рдЬрдЩреНрдЧрдорд╛ред
рддреНрд╡рджреНрдпреБрдХреНрддрдордЦрд┐рд▓ рд╡рд╕реНрддреБ рд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЛрд╜рдкрд┐ рд░рд╛рдШрд╡рееремрейрее

рдХреНрд╖реАрд░рдордзреНрдпрдЧрдд рд╕рдкрд┐рд░реНрдпрдерд╛ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдкреНрдпрд╛рдЦрд┐рд▓ рдкрдпред
рддреНрд╡рджреНрднрд╛рд╕рд╛ рднрд╛рд╕реНрдпрддреЗрд╜рд░реНрдХрд╛рджрд┐рди рддреНрд╡ рддреЗрдирд╛рднрд┐рднрд╛рд╕реНрдпрд╕реЗрееремрекрее

рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдЧ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдореЗрдХ рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдЪрдХреНрд╖реБрд░реНрд╡рд┐рд▓реЛрдХрдпреЗрддреНред
рдпреЛрдЧрд┐рдирд╕реНрддреНрд╡рд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдЪрд┐рдиреНрд╡рдиреНрддрд┐ рд╕реНрд╡рджреЗрд╣реЗ рдкрд░рдореЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░рдореНред

1. рд░рд╛рдо рддреНрд╡рд╕рдХрд▓рд╛рдиреНрддрд░рд╕реНрдердорднрд┐рддреЛ рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рд╕рд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирджреГрдХреНред
рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реАрд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╣реГрджрд┐ рд╕реНрдерд┐рддреЛ рд╣рд┐ рдкрд░рдореЛ рдирд┐рддреНрдпреЛрджрд┐рддреЛ рдирд┐рд░реНрдорд▓ред
рддреНрд╡ рд▓реАрд▓рд╛рдордиреБрдЬрд╛рдХреГрддрд┐ рд╕реБрдорд╣рд┐рдорд╛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛рдЧреБрдгреИрд░реНрдирд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╕реЗреерелреорее

рд▓реАрд▓рд╛рд░реНрде рдкрд░рд┐рдЪреЛрджрд┐рддреЛрд╜рджреНрдп рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рдорд┐ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓рдордирдиреНрддрдордЪрд┐рдиреНрддреНрдп-
рд╢рдХреНрддрд┐ рдЪрд┐рдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдордХреНрд╖рд░рдордЬрдВ рд╡рд┐рджрд┐рддрд╛рддреНрдорддрддреНрддреНрд╡рдореНреерелреорее

2. рддрдереЗрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЬрдЧреНрд░рд╛рд╣ рднрд░рддрд╛рджреНрд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрдореАрд╢реНрд╡рд░ред
рдорд╛рдпрд╛рдорд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдп рд╕рдХрд▓рд╛рдВ рдирд░рдЪреЗрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдореБрдкрд╛рдЧрддреерекрее

of what use was this worldly kingdom to him who is characterized by the feelings of heavenly kingdom and perfect bliss and who is himself the param─Бtman, the unalloyed pleasure in person?At his wink the whole world gets dissolved in an instant, and through his favour the entire universe comes into being. This is only a little of the great creation, created through his l─лl─Б [VI 15 4-6].

(34). R─Бma is the eternal lord of the universe. He has no birth The gods and the asuras, all submit to him, He is thechangeless Hari, N─Бr─Бyaс╣ЗaBrahm─Б, the creator of the universe,

is born from the lotus arising from his navel. The wise conquer the foes in battle by relying on him and the yogins meditate on him through dhy─Бnayoga37┬╣[VII 330-32]

(35) R─Бma, you are the great lord, you know everything through Vijn─Бna.You are the witness to all the three phases of time, past, present and future, you are free from duality For the benefit of the devotees, you appear as doing all the acts under the guse of man38^(2). [VII 4 11 ff].

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╛рдиреБрднрд╡реЛ рдпрд╕реНрдп рд╕реБрдЦрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдиреИрдХрд░реВрдкрд┐рдгред
рдирд┐рд░рд╕реНрддрд╛рддрд┐рд╢рдпрд╛рдирдиреНрджрд░реВрдкрд┐рдг рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдордиред
рдорд╛рдиреБрд╖реЗрдг рддреБ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдпреЗрди рдХрд┐рдВ рддрд╕реНрдп рдЬрдЧрджреАрд╢рд┐рддреБреерелрее

рдпрд╕реНрдпрднреНрд░реБрднрдЩреНрдЧрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рддреНрд░рд┐рд▓реЛрдХреЛ рдирд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛рддред
рдпрд╕реНрдпрд╛рдиреБрдЧреНрд░рд╣рдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдг рднрд╡рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдЦрдгреНрдбрд▓рд╢реНрд░рд┐рдпред
рд▓реАрд▓рд╛рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯрдорд╣рд╛рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯреЗрдГ рдХрд┐рдпрджреЗрд╡рджреНрд░рдорд╛рдкрддреЗрдГрееремрее

1. рднрд░реНрддреНрддрд╛ рдпреЛ рдЬрдЧрддрд╛рдВ рдирд┐рддреНрдп рдпрд╕реНрдп рдЬрдиреНрдорд╛рджрд┐рдХрдВ рди рд╣рд┐ред
рд╕реБрд░рд╛рд╕реБрд░реИрд░реНрдиреБрддреЛ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдВ рд╣рд░рд┐рд░реНрдирд╛рд░рд╛рдпрдгреЛрд╜рд╡реНрдпрдпреерейрежрее

рдпрдиреНрдирд╛рднрд┐рдкрдЩреНрдХрдЬрд╛рдЬреНрдЬрд╛рддреЛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд╕реГрдЬрд╛рдВ рдкрддрд┐ред
рд╕реГрд╖реНрдЯ рдпреЗрдиреИрд╡ рд╕рдХрд▓ рдЬрдЧрддреН рд╕реНрдерд╛рд╡рд░рдЬрдЩреНрдЧрдордореНреерейрезрее

рдд рд╕рдорд╛рд╢реНрд░рд┐рддреНрдп рд╡рд┐рдмреБрдзрд╛ рдЬрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╕рдорд░реЗ рд░рд┐рдкреВрдиреНред
рдпреЛрдЧрд┐рдиреЛ рдзреНрдпрд╛рдирдпреЛрдЧреЗрди рддрдореЗрд╡рд╛рдиреБрдЬрдкрдиреНрддрд┐ рд╣рд┐реерейреирее

2. рд░рд╛рдо рддреНрд╡рдВ рдкрд░рдореЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░реЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рд╕рдХрд▓ рдЬрд╛рдирд╛рд╕рд┐ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирджреГрдЧреН
рднреВрдд рднрд╡реНрдпрдорд┐рдж рддреНрд░рд┐рдХрд╛рд▓рдХрд▓рдирд╛ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реАрд╡рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкреЛрдЬреНрдлрд┐рддред
рднрдХреНрддрд╛рдирд╛рдордиреБрд╡рд░реНрддреНрддрдирд╛рдп рд╕рдХрд▓рд╛рдВ рдХреБрд░реНрд╡рдиреН рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рд╕рд╣рддрд┐рдореН
рдЖрд╢реГрдгреНрд╡рдиреНрдордиреБрдЬрд╛рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реНрдореБрдирд┐рд╡рдЪреЛрднрд╛рд╕реАрд╢ рд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд░реНрдЪрд┐рддрдГреерезрезрее

(36) Kau┼Ыaly─Б tells R─БmaтАФYou are the beginning of the world, but you yourself are free from (the three conditions of) beginning, middle and end. You are the param─Бtman, the ultimate bliss, you are complete andyou are the purusa, the lord39┬╣.

[VII 7 47]

(37) While R─Бma enters the waters of the Saray┼л to end his mundane existence, Brahm─Б comes forward and plays to himтАФ Though you know the secret that you yourself are the sole lord, that you are the complete Visnu, full of ultimate bliss, still, I would make a request, because you are fond of your devotees Save the gods by entering either the sole Vaisnava body with your biothers or any other body which you may like. You are the master of the gods and Vis┼Жu in personтАФ nobody except me knows that At the request of Brahm─Б, while the gods were looking at the great manifestation, R─Бma assumed the form of Visnu with four hands adorned with discus and other weapons, Laksmana assumed the form of the serpent ┼Ъesa and served as the bed of the god. The two sons of Kaikeyi assumed the forms of the discus and the conch and S─лt─Б became Laksm─лR─Бma, with his brothers, thus got back his former body, that of Vis┼Жu, the ancient Being40┬▓. [VII 9 51-56]

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. рд░рд╛рдо рддреНрд╡рдЬрдЧрддрд╛рдорд╛рджрд┐рд░рд╛рджрд┐рдордзреНрдпрд╛рдиреНрддрд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддред
рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рдкрд░рд╛рдирдиреНрдж, рдкреВрд░реНрдг рдкреБрд░реБрд╖ рдИрд╢реНрд╡рд░’реерекренрее

2. рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБ рд╕рджрд╛рдирдиреНрджрдордпреЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рдкреВрд░реНрдгреЛрдЬрд╛рдирд╛рд╕рд┐ рддрддреНрддреНрд╡ рдирд┐рдЬрдореИрд╢рдореЗрдХрдореНред
рддрдерд╛рд╜рдкрд┐ рджрд╛рд╕рд╕реНрдп рдордорд╛рдЦрд┐рд▓реЗрд╢ рдХреГрдд рд╡рдЪреЛ рднрдХреНрддрдкрд░реЛрд╜рд╕рд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрд╡рдиреНреерелрезрее

рддреНрд╡ рднреНрд░рд╛рддреГрднрд┐рд╡реИрд╖реНрдгрд╡рдореЗрдХрдорд╛рджреНрдп рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрдп рджреЗрд╣ рдкрд░рд┐рдкрд╛рд╣рд┐ рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдиреНред
рдпрджреНрд╡рд╛рдкрд░реЛрд╡рд╛ рдпрджрд┐ рд░реЛрдЪрддреЗ рдд рдкреНрд░рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрдп рджреЗрд╣ рдкрд░рд┐рдкрд╛рд╣рд┐ рдирд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдореНреерелреирее

рддреНрд╡рдореЗрд╡ рджреЗрд╡рд╛рдзрд┐рдкрддрд┐рд╢реНрдЪ рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБрд░реНрдЬрд╛рдирдиреНрддрд┐ рди рддреНрд╡рд╛рдВ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╛ рд╡рд┐рдирд╛ рдорд╛рдореНреерелрейрее

рдкрд┐рддрд╛рдорд╣рдкреНрд░рд╛рд░реНрдердирдпрд╛ рд╕рд░рд╛рдордкрд╢реНрдпрддреНрд╕реБ рджреЗрд╡реЗрд╖реБ рдорд╣рд╛рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢.ред
рдореБрд╖реНрдгрд╛рд╢реНрдЪ рдЪрдХреНрд╖реБрд╖рд┐ рджрд┐рд╡реМрдХрд╕рд╛ рддрджрд╛ рдмрднреВрд╡ рдЪрдХреНрд░рд╛рджрд┐рдпреБрддрд╢реНрдЪрддреБрд░реНрднреБрдЬреерелрекрее

рд╢реЗрд╖реЛ рдмрднреВрд╡реЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░рддрд▓реНрдкрднреВрддрдГ рд╕реМрдорд┐рддреНрд░рд┐рд░рддреНрдпрджреНрднреБрддрднреЛрдЧрдзрд╛рд░реМред
рдмрднреВрд╡рддреБрд╢реНрдЪрдХреНрд░рджрд░реМ рдЪ рджрд┐рд╡реНрдпреМ рдХреИрдХреЗрдпреАрд╕реВрдиреБрд░реНрд▓рд╡рдгрд╛рдиреНрддрдХрд╢реНрдЪреерелрелрее

рд╕реАрддрд╛ рдЪ рд▓рдХреНрд╖реНрдореАрд░рднрд╡рддреН рдкреБрд░реИрд╡ рд░рд╛рдореЛ рд╣рд┐ рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгреБ. рдкреБрд░реБрд╖ рдкреБрд░рд╛рдг.ред
рд╕рд╣рд╛рдиреБрдЬрдГ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╢рд░реАрд░рдХреЗрдг рдмрднреВрд╡ рддреЗрдЬреЛрдордпрджрд┐рд╡реНрдпрдореВрд░реНрддреНрддрд┐реерелремрее

From the foregoing passages it is clear that the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana represents R─Бma as the Par─Бtman, the Param─Бtman on the BrahmanтАФ the ultimate Being As such, R─Бma possesses all the characteristics of the Brahman. He is sat, cit and ─БnandaтАФ being, consciousness and bliss. He is free from duality, fiee from change and free from attributes Like the Purusa of S─Бmkhya, “he neither moves norstays, neither repents nordesires, neither abandons nordoes anythingтАЭ He is identical with the ┼Ъabda-Brahman or the Pranura, i.e, the sound Om.

From a Vaisnavite point of view, R─Бma is the same as Visnu, N─Бr─Бyana All other gods

Vrii┼Иc─▒, Brahm─Б, ┼Ъiva etc, are only his secondary forms. It is he who incarnates as Matsya, K┼лrma, ┼Ъ┼лkara, Narasimha, etc. He is thus the lord of the world It is he, who, under different forms, plays the different roles of the gods of creation, destruction and preservation (Brahm─Б, ┼Ъiva and Visс╣Зu) But these gods also are the creations of тАШm─Бy─Б’. M─Бy─Б, which is the primordial source of the world, has a three-fold character. These aspects are determined by the three constituents (guna) of m─Бy─Б, namely sattva, rajas and tamas. The three gods Visnu, Brahm─Б and Rudra are created respectively by those three constituents. But R─Бma, the Par─Бtman transcends all these. He is the sole master of creation which comes into being from his reflection through the m─Бy─Б.

III

The Maya and the Creation

While R─Бma, the Par─Бtman, transcends the universe and does not create anything, it is Sit─Б, conceived as m─Бy─Б or yogam─Бy─Б, who brings into existence the whole creation. She is called (apparently under the inspiration of the Tantra-┼Ъ─Бstras) yogam─Бy─Б only in a few passages, while more frequently she is m─Бy─Б. She is also called the m┼лlaprakrti simply the prakrti. She creates ceaselessly while she is near the Par─Бtman Her relation with the latter is that of foam with water or fire with smoke When she envelopes the Par─Бtman, the creation starts. The Par─Б

tman really does not act His relation with the creative m─Бy─Б is that of the magnet with the iron.

The author of Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana, we have seen, uses various words as synonyms of m─Бy─Б-avy─Бkrta, ┼Ыakti, m┼лlaprakrti, avidy─Б, samsrti,bandha, prakrt─▒, etc. The evolution of the phenomenal universe starts from her.But before we can try to determine the order of this evolution it is necessary to discuss the passages bearing upon the question.

(1) M─Бy─Б is like the foam in water and smoke in fire. The Param─Бtman is the subject (─Бdh─Бra), while m─Бy─Б is the object (visaya). It is the latter which creates When the cit┼Ыakt─▒ (consciousness) reflects itself in the material world, created through avidy─Б, it comes to be known as the J─лva on the individual being With the rise of egoism (abhim─Бna) in regard to the body, mind, vital force (pr─Бna), intellect (buddhi) etc, arises the sense of distinction between the subject and the object, pleasure and painetc. But from the point of view of the ultimate reality, there is no transmigration (samsrt─▒) of the ─Бtman. The Buddhi or the intellect is never the same as knowledge (j├▒─Бna). It is through the error of distinction that the world comes into being and the matter combined with the spirit appears as conscious though it

really remains unconscious. The combination is like that of the lightning and the cloud41┬╣. [I. 7. 28-33]

(2) The ignorance in the shape of apparent knowledge is what is called the unmanifested (avy─Бkrta). From the unmanifested arises the mahat and from the mahat, the s┼лtra orthe ahamk─Бraa (self-sense). The self-sense produces the subtle body (lingadeha), with all its attributes and from that originate the five sense-organs. It is in this way that the J─лva on the individual comes into being and fills the world. Thus avidy─Бor illusion, which is eternal and indescribable, is the cause, the limiting adjunct (up─Бdhi). The cit or consciousness has three attributesтАФ the cause (avidy─Б), the subtle and the gross. The Java is possessed of these but when he is free from these, he becomes identical with the ultimate Being. These three attributes of the cit correspond to the three states of j─Бgratat, svapna and susupti (awakening, dream and deep sleep). The ┼Ъ─Бks─лn is free from these three states.He is the cit alone and R─Бma is the same as he42┬▓. [II 1. 18-22].

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

1.рдпрдерд╛ рдЬрд▓реЗ рдлреЗрдирдмреНрд░рдиреНрдж рдзреВрдореЛ рд╡рд╣реНрдиреМ рддрдерд╛ рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ред
рддреНрд╡рджрд╛рдзрд╛рд░рд╛ рддреНрд╡рджреНрджреНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпрд╛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдп рд╕реГрдЬрддреНрдпрд╣реЛреереиреорее

рдпрд╛рд╡рдиреНрдорд╛рдпрд╛рд╡реГрддрд╛ рд▓реЛрдХрд╛рд╕реНрддрд╛рд╡рддреН рддреНрд╡рд╛ рди рд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдирддреЗред
рдЕрд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рд┐рддрд╕рд┐рджреНрдзреИрд╖рд╛рд╜рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд┐рд░реЛрдзрд┐рдиреМреереиреорее

рдЕрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдХреГрддрджреЗрд╣рд╛рджрд┐рд╕рджреНрдШрд╛рддреЗ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрд┐рддрд╛ред
рдЪрд┐рдЪреНрдЫрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реНрдЬреАрд╡рд▓реЛрдХреЗрд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдЮреНрдЬреАрд╡ рдЗрддреНрдпрднрд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗреерейрежрее

рдпрд╛рд╡рджреНрджреЗрд╣рдорди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрдмреБрджреНрдзрд╛рджрд┐рд╖реНрд╡рднрд┐рдорд╛рдирд╡рд╛рдиреНред
рддрд╛рд╡рдд рдХрд░реНрддреНрддреБрддреНрд╡рднреЛрдХреНрддреГрддреНрд╡рд╕реБрдЦрджреБ рдЦрд╛рджрд┐рднрд╛рдЧреН рднрд╡реЗрддреНреерейрезрее

рдЖрддреНрдорди рд╕рд╕реГрддрд┐рд░реНрдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдмреБрджреНрдзреЗрд░реНрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рди рди рдЬрд╛рддреНрд╡рд┐рддрд┐реерейреирее

рдЕрд╡рд┐рд╡реЗрдХрд╛рдж рднреНрд░рдо рдпреБрдХреНрддреНрд╡рд╛ рд╕рд╕рд╛рд░реАрддрд┐ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддреНрддрддреЗред
рдЬрдбрд╕реНрдпрдЪрд┐рддреНрд╕рдорд╛рдпреЛрдЧрд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд┐рддреНрдд рднреВрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд┐рдиреЗрд╕реНрддрдерд╛ред
рдЬрдбрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдЬреНрдЬрдбрддреНрд╡ рд╣рд┐ рдЬрдирд╛рдЧреНрдиреНрдпреЛрд░реНрдореЗрдиреНрдирди рдпрдерд╛реерейрейрее

2. рддреНрд╡рджрд╛рднрд╛рд╕реЛрджрд┐рддрд╛рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдорд╡реНрдпрд╛рдХреГрддрдорд┐рддреАрд░реНрдпрддреЗред
рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреНрдорд╣рд╛рд╕реНрддрдд

рд╕реГрддреНрд░рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╛рддреНрдордХ рддрддреерезреорее

рдЕрд╣рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд░рд╢реНрдЪ рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд╢реНрдЪ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдкреНрд░рд╛рдгреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдгрд┐ рдЪред
рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрдорд┐рддреНрдпрдЪреНрдпрддреЗ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬреНрдЮреИрд░реНрдЬрдиреНрдордореГрддреНрдпрд╕реБрдЦрд╛рджрд┐рдорддреНреерезрепрее

(3) R─Бma as Brahman is without beginning and without end. He is inconceivable and indescribable. He is subtle and is beyond the reach of the two bodies, subtle and gross. He is all consciousness while the rest is all matter When the reflection of the Cit is one with the intellect (Buddha) it becomes the Jiva. Brahman is the S─Бks─лn or the witness of the intellect R─Бma, in his subtle body is the Hiranyagarbha, in his gross body is the Vir─Бt. His subtle body which is inconceivable contains all that is past, present and future. The gross body which is enveloped by the mahat-tattva and other tattvas is within the reach of conception because it possesses ever-increasing gunas43┬╣[III 931-34]

(4) The intellect which gives rise to the self-sense in the material body, which is devoid of consciousness, is m─Бy─Б. The world of transmigration is imagined through its influence. This m─Бy─Б has two forcesтАФ viksepa (projecting) and ─Бvarana (enveloping) The first leads to the creation of the world comprising both the gross and subtle forms and the other envelopes the totality of the universal consciousness. The param─Бtman isimagined as the universe through errorjust as a rope is mistaken for a snake. All that is heard, seen or thought of by men is as false as the dream. The material body is the firm root of the world of transmigrationтАФ it produces all bondage. The material body of the gross beings is

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

рд╕ рдПрд╡ рдЬреАрд╡рд╕рдЬреНрдЮрд╢реНрдЪ рд▓реЛрдХреЗ рднрд╛рддрд┐ рдЬрдЧрдиреНрдордпред
рдЕрд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛рдирд╛рджреНрдпрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпреИрд╡ рдХрд╛рд░рдгреЛрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рд░реБрдЪреНрдпрддреЗреереирежрее

рд╕реНрдереВрд▓ рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рдХрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдореБрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рддреНрд░рд┐рддрдп рдЪрд┐рддреЗред
рдПрддреИрд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛ рдЬреАрд╡ рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рджреНрджрд┐рдореБрдХреНрдд рдкрд░рдореЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░реереирее

рдЬрд╛рдЧреНрд░рддреНрд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдирд╕реБрд╖реБрдкреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рд╕реГрддрд┐рд░реНрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддреНрддрддреЗред
рддрдореНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдг рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реАрдЪрд┐рдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рд░рдШреВрддреНрддрдореереиреирее

1. рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рддреЗ рд░реВрдкрдордиреНрдпрдХреНрдд рджреЗрд╣рджреНрд╡рдпрд╡рд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрдореНред
рджреГ

рдЧреНрд░реБрдкрдорд┐рддрд░рддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рджреГрд╢реНрдп рдЬрдбрдордирд╛рддреНрдордХрдореНред
рддрддреН рдХрде рддреНрд╡рд╛рд╡рд┐рдЬрд╛рдиреАрдпрд╛рдж рд╡реНрдпрддрд┐рд░рд┐рдХреНрдд рдорди рдкреНрд░рднреЛреерейрезрее

рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рддреНрдорд╛рднрд╛рдордпреЛрд░реИрдХреНрдп рдЬреАрд╡ рдЗрддреНрдпрднрд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗред
рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реАрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдореИрд╡ рддрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреЗрд╜рдЦрд┐рд▓рдореНред
рдЖрд░реЛрдкреНрдпрддреЗрд╜рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╡рд╢рд╛рдиреНрдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЗрд╜рдЦрд┐рд▓рд╛рддреНрдордирд┐реерейреирее

рд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрдЧрд░реНрднрд╕реНрддреЗ рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рджреЗрд╣ рд╕реНрдереВрд▓ рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЯреН рд╕реНрдореГрддрдореНред
рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛рд╡рд┐рд╖рдпреА рд░рд╛рдо рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рддреЗ рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдирдордЩреНрдЧрд▓рдореНред
рднреВрдд рднрд╡реНрдп рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрдЪреНрдЪ рдпрддреНрд░реЗрджрдВ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рдЬрдЧрддреНреерейрейрее

рд╕реНрдереВрд▓реЗрд╜рдгреНрдбрдХреЛрд╖реЗ рджреЗрд╣реЗ рддреЗ рдорд╣рджрд╛рджрд┐рднрд┐рд░рд╛рд╡реГрддреЗред
рд╕рдкреНрддрднрд┐рд░реБрддреНрддрд░рдЧреБрдгреИрд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЬреЛрдзрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рд╢реНрд░рдпреерейрекрее.
A-R-5

fivefold, its essence is also fivefold. Besides these there are ahamk─Бra, buddhi, the ten sense-organs (five for action, and five for cognition), the reflection of consciousness, the mind and the m┼лlaprakс╣Ыti.The field (ksetra) consisting of all these is thematerial body, When the individual is free from all these he is the pure param─Бtman44┬╣. [III 4 20-28]

(5) The gross body of illusion is produced by the five gross elements beginning with prthv─л (earth). It is the limiting adjunct (up─Бdhi) of the ─Бtman. It is constituted by the mind (manas), the intellect (buddhi), the ten sense - oigans, the pr─Бna orvital wind and the five tanm─Бtras or subtle substances. The m─Бy─Бis the principal body of the BrahmanтАФ the cause which is eternal and indescribable. The visible difference is due to the adjuncts (up─Бdhi) Just as the crystal (sphatika) appeals to possess the colour of things near it, the jiva orthe idividual soul appears in various colours in the association of the sheaths (kosas) but when rightly judged it appears as fiee from becoming and fiee from duality. The buddh─▒under the influence of the three gunas has three different functions (vitti)тАФ the states of awakening, deep sleep and dreamless sleep (J─Бgrat svapna and susupti). As these gunas are subject to change (vyabhic─Бr─л) then functions in relation to the ultimate Brahma are false45┬▓[VII 5 28-32]

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

1. рдЕрдирд╛рддреНрдордирд┐ рд╢рд░реАрд░рд╛рджрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреНрдордмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд╕реНрддреБ рдпрд╛ рднрд╡реЗрддреНред
рд╕реИрд╡ рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рддрдпреИрд╡рд╛рд╕реМ рдорд╕рд╛рд░ рдкрд░рд┐рдХрд▓реНрдкреНрдпрддреЗреереирежрее

рд░реВрдкреЗ рд╣реЗ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреЗ рдкреВрд░реНрд╡ рдорд╛рдпрдпрд╛ рдХреБрд▓рдирдиреНрджрдиред
рд╡рд┐рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╛рд╡рд░рдгреЗ рддрддреНрд░рдкреНрд░рдердо рдХрд▓реНрдкрд╡реЗрдЬреНрдЬрдЧрддреереирезрее

рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рджреНрдпрд╛рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордкрд░реНрдпрдиреНрдд рд╕реНрдереВрд▓рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдорд╡рд┐рднреЗрджрдд.ред
рдЕрдкрд░ рддреНрд╡рдЦрд┐рд▓ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рди рд░реВрдкрдорд╛рд╡реГрддреНрдп рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐реереиреирее

рдорд╛рдпрдпрд╛ рдХрд▓реНрдкрд┐рдд рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдордирд┐ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓реЗред
рд░рдЬреНрдЬреМ рднреБрдЬрдЩреНрдЧрд╡рджреН рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░реЗ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддрд┐ рдХрд┐рдЮреНрдЪрдиреереирейрее

рд╢реНрд░реВрдпрддреЗ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рдпрджреН рдпрддреН рд╕реНрдорд░реНрдпрддреЗ рд╡рд╛ рдирд░реИ рд╕рджрд╛ред
рдЕрд╕рджреЗрд╡ рд╣рд┐ рддрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдпрдерд╛ рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдирдордиреЛрд░рдереМреереирекрее

рджреЗрд╣ рдПрд╡ рд╣рд┐ рд╕рд╕рд╛рд░ рд╡реГрдХреНрд╖рдореВрд▓ рджреГрдв рд╕реНрдореГрддрдореНред
рддрдиреНрдореВрд▓ рдкреБрддреНрд░рджрд╛рд░рд╛рджрд┐рд╡рдиреНрдз рд╕реЛрд╜рдкреНрдпрдиреНрдпрдерд╛рддреНрдордиреереирелрее

рджреЗрд╣рд╕реНрддреБ рд╕реНрдереВрд▓рднреВрддрд╛рдирд╛ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрддрдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдХрдореНред
рдЕрд╣рдЩреНрдХрд╛рд░рд╢реНрдЪ рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд╢реНрдЪрдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рдгрд┐ рддрдерд╛ рджрд╢реереиремрее

рдЪрд┐рджрд╛рднрд╛рд╕реЛ рдордирд╢реНрдЪреИрд╡ рдореВрд▓рдкреНрд░рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реЗрд╡ рдЪред
рдПрддрддреН рдХреНрд╖реЗрддреНрд░рдорд┐рддрд┐ рдЬреНрдЮреЗрдп рджреЗрд╣ рдЗрддреНрдпрднрд┐рдзреАрдпрддреЗреереиренрее

рдПрддреИрд░реНрд╡рд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгреЛ рдЬреАрд╡ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рдирд┐рд░рд╛рдордпред
рддрд╕реНрдп рдЬреАрд╡рд╕реНрдп рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдиреЗ рд╕рд╛рдзрдирд╛рдиреНрдпрдкрд┐рд╢реГрдгреБреереиреорее

2. рд░рд╕рд╛рджрд┐рдкрдЮреНрдЪреАрдХреГрддрднреВрддрд╕рдореНрднрд╡ рднреЛрдЧрд╛рд▓рдп рджреБрдГрдЦрд╕реБрдЦрд╛рджрд┐рдХрд░реНрдордгрд╛рдореНред
рд╢рд░реАрд░рдорд╛рджреНрдпрдиреНрддрд╡рджрд╛рджрд┐рдХрд░реНрдордЬ рдорд╛рдпрд╛рдордп рд╕реНрдереВрд▓рдореБрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рдорд╛рддреНрдордиреереиреорее

Thus according to the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana the creation of the universe starts from S─лt─Б who is the m┼лlaprakrti, the primordial cause. This m┼лlaprakrti for him, is the same as the m─Бy─Бor the avdiy─Б, avy─Бkrta or the unmanifested of the Ved─Бnta, the pradh─Бna of the S─Бmkhya and the ┼Ъakti of the Tantra┼Ы─Бstras. The Prakiti, under the influence of its three gunas or constituentsтАФ the sattva, rajas and tamasтАФ creates the universe. The order of evolution starting from the prakit╔й isтАФ mahat, the great principle of creation (also called the buddhi), the ahamk─Бra, the tendency of individualisation, the five subtle substances (pa├▒catanm─Бtras), the five gross elements (mah─Бbh┼лtas), the five senseorgans (pa├▒ca-karmendriyas) and (pa├▒ca-j├▒─Бnendriyas) as well as the mind. The order of this evolution may be indicated in a schematic way as followsтАФ

<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1725951686Capture.JPG”/>

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рдордиреЛрдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рджрд╢реЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпреИ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгреИрд░рдкрдЮреНрдЪреАрдХреГрддрднреВрддрд╕рдореНрднрд╡рдореНред
рднреЛрдХреНрддреБ рд╕реБрдЦрд╛рджреЗрд░рдиреБрд╕рд╛рдзрди рднрд╡реЗрдЪреНрдЫрд░реАрд░рдордиреНрдпрджреН рд╡рд┐рджреБрд░рд╛рддреНрдордиреЛ рдмреБрдзрд╛реереиреорее

рдЕрдирд╛рджреНрдпрдирд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрдордкреАрд╣ рдХрд╛рд░рдг рдорд╛рдпрд╛рдкреНрд░рдзрд╛рдирдиреНрддреБ рдкрд░ рд╢рд░реАрд░рдХрдореНред
рдЙрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рднреЗрджрд╛рддреНрддреБ рдпрдд рдкреГрдердХреНрд╕реНрдерд┐рдд рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рддреНрдорд╛рдирдорд╛рддреНрдордиреНрдпрд╡рдзрд╛рд░рдпреЗрддреН рдХреНрд░рдорд╛рддреНреерейрежрее

рдХреЛрд╢реЗрд╖реБ рдкрдЮреНрдЪрд╕реНрд╡рдкрд┐ рддрддреНрддрджрд╛рдХреГрддрд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рднрд╛рддрд┐ рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╛рдд рд╕реНрдлрдЯрд┐рдХреЛрдкрд▓реЛ рдпрдерд╛ред
рдЕрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд░реВрдкреЛрд╜рдпрдордЬреЛ рдпрддреЛрд╜рджреНрд╡рдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдп рддреЗрд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкрд░рд┐рддреЛ рд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рд┐рддреЗреерейрезрее

рдмреБрджреНрдзреЗрд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдзрд╛ рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рд░рдкреАрд╣ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдирд╛рджрд┐рднреЗрджреЗрди рдЧреБрдгрддреНрд░рдпрд╛рддреНрдордиред
рдЕрдиреНрдпреЛрдиреНрдпрддреЛрд╜рд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рд╡реНрдпрднрд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рддреЛ рдореГрд╖рд╛ рдирд┐рддреНрдпреЗ рдкрд░реЗ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгрд┐ рдХреЗрд╡рд▓реЗ рд╢рд┐рд╡реЗреерейреирее

[variant for рдордиреЛрдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рджрд╢реЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпреИтАФрдордиреЛрдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░рд╣рдХреНрд░рд┐рдпреЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпреИ]

So far the order of the evolution agrees with the S─Бmkhya system, according to which the m┼лlaprakiti is the primordial cause of the creation. The S─Бmkhya calls it the m┼лlaprakiti as it is the root of the creation. It is also called pradh─Бna because it is the original principle. At this stage the prakitiremains unman─▒festedтАФ ay─Бkrta. At the next stage when the evolution starts it is ay─Бkrta or manifested. At this stage is produced the mahat, the great principle, also called the buddhiтАФ the intellect orthe phenomenal spirit which is imbibed in the matter and organises it from within. The mahat then produces the ahamk─БraтАХthe sense of self or a tendency towards individualisation From this selfsense arise the five subtle elements (pa├▒catanm─Бtra)тАФ the sound (┼Ыabda), the touch (spar─Бa), the form (r┼лpa), the taste (rasa) and the smell (gandha) From these five subtle elements evolve, the rest of the creationтАФ the five gross elements (mah─Бbh┼лta), the five sense-organs relating either to the buddhi or the harma and the mind. The part has three constituents orgunasтАФ the sattva, rajas and tamas and the course of the evolution is determined by them.

But when the question of the relation between the prakitiand the ─Бtman arises the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana does not always adhere to the S─Бmkhya view. The S─Бmkhya is dualistic and according to it the purusa does not create, it is the prakrti which creates the world. Though prakrti primarily receives the impetus from the Purusa the latter does not really act His presence alone sets Prakrti in motion. The author of the Adhy─Бtma- R─Бm─Бyana often makes similarutterances, for example, when he says that the m─Бy─Бwhich, though inanimate, creates the world as the immovable metals move in the proximity of the magnet (рдпрдерд╛ рдЪреБрдореНрдмрдХрд╕рд╛рдиреНрдирд┐рдзреНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд▓рдиреНрддреНрдпреЗрд╡рд╛рдЪрд▓рд╛рджрдпрдГред рдЬрдбрд╛ рддрдерд╛ рддреНрд╡рдпрд╛ рджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рд╕реГрдЬрддрд┐ рд╡реИ рдЬрдЧрддреНрее), orwhen he says that the m─Бy─Б acts being goaded on by the Purusa. It is also under the influence of S─Бmkhya that he speaks of prakrti as the m┼лlaprakrti and represents Sit─Б as such. But ultimately he says that the prakrti is nothing but the m─Бy─Б, the illusion. It is only the limiting adjunct (up─Бdhi) of the Brahman.

It arises out of his reflection and is comparable either to the foam in water or the smoke in fire. The world is a world of appearance and from the point of view of the ultimate reality it has no separate entity. With the rise of a knowledge of reality it disappears from our view and the Brahman alone remains.

In regard to the relation between the Brahman and the world a slightly different shade of opinion, that of the Vi┼Ыist─Бdvaita of R─Бm─Бnuja, has also been introduced by the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana. The worldly form of R─Бma is not unimportant to him. R─Бma is said to have assumed the human form (though illusory) for the benefit of the devotees who cannot otherwise approach him. Besides in VII 1 58, R─Бma is invoked as one who has assumed the form of man through l─лl─Б and not under the influence of the gunus of m─Бy─Б and has been sent to perform his l─лl─БтАФ

рддреНрд╡ рд▓реАрд▓рд╛рдордиреБрдЬрд╛рдХреГрддрд┐рдГ рд╕реБрдорд╣рд┐рдорд╛ рдорд╛рдпрд╛рдЧреБрдгреИрд░реНрдирд╛рдЬреНрдпрд╕реЗред
рд▓реАрд▓рд╛рд░реНрде рдкрд░рд┐рдЪреЛрджрд┐рддреЛрд╜рджреНрдп рднрд╡рддрд╛ рд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐ рд░рдХреНрд╖реЛрджреНрднрд╡рдореНрее

As is well-known, the Vi┼Ыist─Бdvaita admits that Brahman reveals Itself as a cosmic force through its l─лl─Бvibh┼лti with the help of the Prakrti whereas the ┼Ъuddh─Бdvaita throws down this revelation as completely illusory.

But as the author of Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana only makes a passing reference to this aspect of the relation between Brahman and the world, does not develop it further and lays greater stress on the illusory character of this relation, it may be said that he sides entirely with the ┼Ъuddh─Бdvaita school

IV

The world as an Illusion

When the sole reality is the Brahman and the creation comes into being through illusion, the world of being is also unreal and phenomenal. Therefore, all our relations with this illusory world are equally illusory. As these relations are illusory it is useless to be moved by pleasure, pain, sorrow, happiness, hatred, Jealousy etc. As separation from a deal one orunion with him is illusory it is useless to be pained by his death. Death only removes the material body which comes into being through the m─Бy─БтАФ the j─лvaor the ultimate reality behind it is not subject to death or to any other change. It is our ignorance which gives rise to the senses of distinction like brith, death, oldage etc. The ultimate reality, the ─Бtman or the Brahman is free from all changes, is immovable and imperishable. He is omnipresent, ever blissful and transcends the world of transmigration which exists only as long as our false sense as to the true nature of the reality continues to be active

These views are stated by the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana in a large number of passagesтАФ

(1) While Guha out of pity for the hardship of R─Бma blames Kaikey─л, Laksmaс╣Зa says unto himтАФ nobody really causes either pleasure or pain to anybody. The karma accumulated by oneself is the cause of pleasure and pain. Nobody is the agent of one’s sorrow and pain. Through false self-sense man considers himself to be the agent. The whole world is tied down to the chain of harma. It is through a similarerrorthat man attributes his own karma to others, the pleasure and pain, are also due to one’s own karma. One, therefore, ought to suffer it as it comes and thus attain the equilibrium of the mind. One ought not to have any desire because desire is the cause of all misery. In whatever place and time one performs good or

bad action one suffers from the effect then and there. Therefore, one should not be moved either by pleasure or pain on account of good and evilтАФ it is impossible to get rid of things which must happen. The man is bound down by pleasure and painтАФ the material body is produced by merit and demerit in the same way as pleasure and pain There is pain after pleasure and pleasure after pain. Both are unavoidable by beings like the day and night. Pain lies within pleasure and pleasure within pain. Both are naturally related like water and mud. The wise, therefore, through a right knowledge, do not feel either happy orsad at gain or loss after considering that all is illusion (рд╕рд░реНрд╡ рдорд╛рдпреЗрддрд┐ рднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛рддреН) [II 6 4-15]

(2) When B─Бl─лis killed by R─Бma his wife T─Бr─Б becomes extremely moved by sorrow but R─Бma consoles her thusтАФ why are you aggrieved for him who ought not to be the object of grief. Tell me whether this body or the j─лva is your husband. The material body, possessed of skin, flesh, blood and bone and made of the five elements, is the creation of time, karma and the gunas (orthe inherent powers of Prakiti). Therefore, your husband still exists (though his material body has fallen) Know that the j─лva is the ─Бtman, the j─лva, therefore, is not subject to any suffering, it neither comes into existence nor dies, it neither stays nor goes away, It is neither female nor male norof a neuter character. It is real, immovable and imperishable. It is the sole reality, free from duality, as free as the space. It is eternal, full of consciousness and pure. There is, therefore, no cause of grief.

When R─Бma had said this T─Бr─Б puts to him the question, if the body is like a piece of wood and if the j─лva is eternal and characterized by consciousness then to whom do the pleasure and pain appertain? Thereupon R─Бma repliesтАФ as long as there is relation of the self-sense (ahamk─Бra) with the body and the sense-organs, the world of transmigration continues to exist for the j─лva. This world of transmigration is imagined through false knowledge though it does not really exist just as the objects thought of appear in

a dream. The self-sense (ahamkrti) arises through the influence of eternal avidy─Бand the world, though unreal, becomes full of anger, Jealousy etc. The mind itself is the world and the bondage is also the mind. So long as this mind is considered to be the same as the ─Бtman the bondage continues to remain. Just as a piece of pure crystal, though itself free from all colours, assumes the colour of an object near it, the ─Бtman in the proximity of the intellect (buddhi) and the sense-organs appears to be under the influence. The ─Бtman, in the association of the mind created by its subtle body (рд╕реНрд╡рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧ), stays in this world powerless under the influence of the gunas and fulfils the desires of the world. The j─лva creates the gunas and the mind, first of all, then the karma of various kinds white, red and black and thereafter the states of existence coesponding to them. The j─лva then transmigrates in this worldunder the influence of these harmas. At the time of the dissolution, the j─лva lives in the association of the eternal avidy─Бand the desires and the karmas and at the time of creation comes into being with them. As soon as one realizes that the ─Бtman, which is real, blissful and fiee from duality, is different from the body, the sense-organs, the mind etc, he at once gets liberated [IV 3 14-30]

(3) On the death of Da┼Ыaratha while Bharata is overwhelmed with grief Va┼Ыistha consoles him as followsтАФ you are aggrieved in vain for that which has been liberated. The ─Бtman (soul) is eternal, unchangeable, pure and free from birth and death. The body is material, impure and subject to destiuction. There is, therefore, no reason to be aggrieved if you think over it calmly It is only the ignorant who is aggrieved on the death of a father, mother or son. In this unreal world of transmigration separation from the deal ones serves as the cause of vair─Бgya (renunciation) and conduces to peace and happiness. Birth in this world is followed by death, Death is, therefore, inevitable to those who are born. As birth and death of all beings are due to theirown karma the wise should not be aggrieved at the death of relatives. Crores of worlds have been destroyed, creations have disappeared many a time and even the oceans get dried. One ought not to have any

attachment to that which is transient. The life is as transient as the drop of water on the shaky leaves. The individual attains the material body through the influence of his previous karma, and then one material body begets another. As one throws away an old dress and puts on a new oneso also the ─Бtman abandons anold body and gets a new one.There is, therefore, no occasion forfeeling aggrieved’The ─Бtman neither dies nor is born. It isfree from the sixstates of transmigration, is eternal and theconsciousness itself.

It is bliss in person, the s─Бks─▒n or the witness to the buddhi and is free from decay. The ─Бtman is free from duality and is present everywhere alike (II 7 86-98]

(4) On the death of Meghan─Бda when Mandodari becomes overwhelmed by grief R─Бvaс╣Зa consoles he thusтАФ Abandon your grief through sure knowledge of the reality. Grief arises out of ignorance and destroys the night knowledge. The self-sense (ahamdh─лh) in the illusory body and not in the ─Бtman arises through the influence of ignorance. That again serves as the root of all worldly relations and bondage. Pleasure, pain, fear, anger, avarice,
desire etc, arise out of ignorance, and birth, death, oldage etc, are also due to it. The ─Бtman alone is pure, free and unattached.It is bliss itself, the consciousness and free from the conditions of the mind. Neither connection nor separation exists for that which is real [VI 10 29-33]

(5) On the death of R─Бvaс╣Зa when Vibhisana is upset by grief Laksmana consoles the latter as followsтАФ For whom do you feel aggrieved? What was he to you? What were you to him? As you had no relation with him in the past and as you will have no relation with him in the future, your relation with him during the intermediate period is imaginary. The individual (j─лva) is characterized by his material bodyтАФ one material body begets another just as the seed begets seed. The differentiation between the j─лva and the material body is due to avidy─Б[So on the disappearance of avidy─Б no difference remains] The diversity

A-R-6

brith, death, decay, increase, the retributionтАФ all appeal to the j─лva as pertaining to himself. These modifications are attributed to the ─Бtman through illusory knowledge Just as a hotel seems lively on the influx of men but is silent in the absence, so also through illusion the diversity comes into existence but when the sense of self (ahamk─Бra) slumbers, the bondage no longer exists One who is free from the self-sense (ahamk─Бra) is liberated even in this life. Therefore, abandon this attraction because it is only a habit of the illusory mind, Resign your mind unto the Bhagav─Бn R─Бma, the god, the ─Бtman of all creation, the ultimate Being under the illusory form of man [VI 12 9-18]

V

Atman, Jiva, Saks─▒n and Isvara

While the mahat or the buddhi, the sole cause of creation pertains to the world of illusion, the ─Бtman transcends it. It is

complete in itself and is free from change and the limiting adjuncts. It is self-luminous and the sole consciousness that is real. There is no other reality except the ─Бtman46┬╣.

There is no essential difference between the individual soul (j─лva) and the ─Бtman47**┬▓.**The differentiation comes into existence only through illusory knowledge. When this illusion is dissipated the two become identical48┬│. “The j─лva is the ─Бtman, it neither comes into being nordies, it neither stays no goes away.It has no sex, and is immovable and imperishable. It is the sole reality which is free from duality and as fiee as the space, It is the pure eternal consciousness49^(4)” If the J─лva is such it is without doubt identical with the ─Бtman.

The distinction between the ─Бtman (=jiv─Бtman) and the par─Бtman is brought out by the classical analogy of the space. The space has three aspectsтАФ the unlimited space above, the limited space within the water pot and the space reflected in the water. The supreme consciousness has similarly three aspectsтАФ the supreme unconditional consciousness, the consciousness limited by the intellect

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

1. рдЖрддреНрдорд╛ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рддреНрд░ рдкреВрд░реНрдг рд╕реНрд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдЪрд┐рджрд╛рдирдиреНрджрд╛рддреНрдордХреЛрд╜рд╡реНрдпрдпред
рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рджреНрдпреБрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рд░рд╣рд┐рдд рдкрд░рд┐рдгрд╛рдорд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрее

рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢реЗрди рджреЗрд╣рд╛рджреАрдиреН рднрд╛рд╕рдпрдиреНрдирдирдкрд╛рд╡реГрддред
рдПрдХ рдПрд╡рд╛рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпрд╢реНрдЪрд╕рддреНрдпрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╛рджрд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгред
рдЕрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрд░рднреЛ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдиреЗрдирд╛рд╡рдЧрдореНрдпрддреЗрее[III. 4.38-39]

2.рдЬреАрд╡рд╢реНрдЪ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рдЪ рдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдпреЛ рдирд╛рддреНрд░ рднреЗрджрдзреАред [III. 4.29]

3. рд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпрд╢рд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд░реЛрдкрджреЗрд╢рд╛рджреИрдХреНрдпрдЬреНрдЮрд╛рди рдпрджрд╛ рднрд╡реЗрддред
рдЖрддреНрдордиреЛрд░реНрдЬреАрд╡рдкрд░рдпреЛрд░реНрдореНрд▓рд╛рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛ рддрджреИрд╡ рд╣рд┐рее

рд▓реАрдпрддреЗ рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдХрд░рдгреИрдГ рд╕рд╣реИрд╡ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдордирд┐ред
рд╕рд╛рд╜рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рдореБрдХреНрддрд┐рд░рд┐рддреНрдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛ рд╣реНрдпреБрдкрдЪрд╛рд░реЛрд╜рд╣рдорд╛рддреНрдордирд┐рее[III 4.40-41]

4. рдордиреНрдпрд╕реЗ рдЬреАрд╡рдорд╛рддреНрдорд╛рди рдЬреЛрд╡рд╕реНрддрд░реНрд╣рд┐рдирд┐рд░рд╛рдордпред
рди рдЬрд╛рдпрддреЗ рди рдореНрд░рд┐рдпрддреЗ рди рддрд┐рд╖реНрдарддрд┐ рди рдЧрдЪреНрдЫрддрд┐рее

рди рд╕реНрддреНрд░реА рдкреБрдорд╛рдиреН рд╡рд╛ рд╖рдгреНрдбреЛ рд╡рд╛ рдЬреАрд╡рд╕рддреНрдпрдЧрддреЛрд╜рд╡реНрдпрдп.ред
рдПрдХ рдПрд╡рд╛рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдпреЛрд╜рдпрдорд╛рдХрд╛рд╢рд╡рджрд▓реЗрдкрдХрдГред
рдирд┐рддреНрдпреЛ рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирдордпрдГ рд╢реБрджреНрдзрдГ рд╕ рдХрдердВ рд╢реЛрдХрдорд░реНрд╣рддрд┐рее[IV. 3.15-16]

(or the internal organs) and the consciousness that is reflected in the intellect. The S─Бksinis free from the changes and limitations which the intellect undergoes50┬╣

** **In order to bring out the distinction between j─лva, ─Бtman and S─Бksinfurther the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana says.

The limiting adjuncts are of three kindsтАФ gross (sth┼лla), subtle (s┼лksma) and causal (h─Бranop─Бdhi). These form the gross material body constituted by the five elements, the subtle body (lingadeha ors┼лtram) constituted by self-sense, intellect and the senses and the eternal and indescribable avidy─Б. That which possesses all these adjuncts is the J─лva and that which is free from them is the Parame┼Ыvara [рд╕реНрдереВрд▓ рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рдХрд╛рд░рдгрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдореБрдкрд╛рд╡рд┐рддреНрд░рд┐рддрдп рдЪрд┐рддреЗрдГред рдПрддреИрд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛ рдЬреАрд╡рдГ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рджреНрд╡рд┐рдореБрдХреНрддрдГ рдкрд░рдореЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░рдГ]. These three conditions of illusion correspond to the three statesтАФ of waking, sleep and deep sleep. The S─Бksin, the sole consciousness transcends them and thus forms the fourth (tur─лya) onthe last stage.

The author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana is not quite clear on the state of ─к┼Ыvara which is not free from the limiting adjunct. Though it does not possess the first two adjuncts, namely, the gross and the subtle, as stated above, it is not free from the influence of illusion. The susuptior deep sleep to which it corresponds is not fiee from the influx of the illusory world. Of the various commentators

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

1. рдЖрдХрд╛рд╢рд╕реНрдп рдпрдерд╛ рднреЗрджрд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рд╡рд┐рдзреЛ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рдорд╣рд╛рдиреНред
рдЬрд▓рд╛рд╢рдпреЗ рдорд╣рд╛рдХрд╛рд╢рд╕реНрддрджрд╡рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрди рдПрд╡ рд╣рд┐ред
рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрд╛рдЦреНрдпрдордкрд░ рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддреЗ рд╡рд┐рд╡рд┐рдз рдирдн’рее

рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╡рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрдирдЪреИрддрдиреНрдпрдореЗрдХ рдкреВрд░реНрдгрдВ рддрдерд╛рд╜рдкрд░рдореНред
рдЖрднрд╛рд╕рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдкрд░ рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрднреВрддрдореЗрд╡ рддреНрд░рд┐рдзрд╛ рдЪрд┐рддрд┐рдГрее

рдЖрднрд╛рд╕рдмреБрджреНрдзреЗ рдХрд░реНрддреНрддреБрдВрддреНрд╡рдорд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрдиреЗрд╜рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд┐ред
рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреНрдпрд╛рд░реЛрдкреНрдпрддреЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рдЬреАрд╡рддреНрд╡рдЮреНрдЪ рддрдерд╛рд╜рдмреБрдзреИрее[I 1105-107]

cf also VII 5.40.

рдЕрдирд╛рджреНрдпрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпреЛрджреНрднрд╡рдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рдмрд┐рдореНрдмрд┐рддреЛ рдЬреАрд╡. рдкреНрд░рдХрд╛рд╢реЛрд╜рдпрдорд┐рддреЛрд░реНрдпрддреЗ рдЪрд┐рддрдГред
рдЖрд╛рддреНрдорд╛ рдзрд┐рдпрдГ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рддрдпрд╛ рдкреГрдердХреН рд╕реНрдерд┐рддреЛ рдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛ рдкрд░рд┐рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрдирдкрд░рдГ рд╕ рдПрд╡ рд╣рд┐рее

The reflection of the cit in the intellect is the j─лva, whereas ─Бtman is the s─БksinтАФ the witness.

R─Бmavarman has presented the right points of view inspite of the text.R─Бmavarman says thatтАФ the gross adjunct is the gross material body of which the aggregate represents the Vir─Бt, the subtle adjunct is the subtle body of which the aggregate represents the Hiranyagarbha, and causal adjunct is the I┼Ыvara. The J─лva Is possessed of all these adjuncts and I┼Ыvara is included within them because he penetrates into them. The fourth state, which transcends all these adjuncts, represents the Parame┼Ыvara In support of this interpretation R─Бmavarman quotes the V─Бrttika51which saysтАФ the god (─к┼Ыa) has three limiting adjunctsтАФVir─Бt, Hiranyagarbha and K─Бrana. The fourth state transcends all these

[рд╕реНрдереВрд▓ рд╕реНрдереВрд▓рджреЗрд╣рд╕реНрддрддреНрд╕рдорд╖реНрдЯреНрдпреБрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рд░реНрд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЯреН, рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдо рд▓рд┐рдЩреНрдЧрджреЗрд╣рд╕реНрддрддреНрд╕рдорд╖реНрдЯреНрдпреБрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рд░реНрд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрдЧрд░реНрднрдГ, рдХрд╛рд░рдгреЛрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рд░реАрд╢реНрд╡рд░, рдПрддреИрд░реНрд╡рд┐рд╢рд┐рд╖реНрдЯреЛ рдЬреАрд╡, рдЕрдиреНрддрд░реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐рддрдпрд╛ рдИрд╢реНрд╡рд░рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рддрддреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд░реНрднрд╛рд╡рд╛рддреНред рдЙрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рддреНрд░рдпрд╡рд┐рдореБрдХреНрддреЛ рдпрдГ рд╕ рдкрд░рдореЗрд╢реНрд╡рд░рд╕реНрддреБрд░реАрдп рдЗрддреНрдпрд░реНрдеред

рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдбреН рд╣рд┐рд░рдгреНрдпрдЧрд░реНрднрд╢реНрдЪрдХрд╛рд░рдгрдЮреНрдЪреЗрддреНрдпреБрдкрд╛рдзрдпрдГред
рдИрд╢рд╕реНрдп рдпрд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рднрд┐рд╣реАрди рддреБрд░реАрдп рддрддреН рдкрдж рд╡рд┐рджреБрдГрее

рдЗрддрд┐ рд╡рд╛рд░реНрддреНрддрд┐рдХреЛрдХреНрддреЗрдГред]

The order of this evolution according to the author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бmay─Бna seems to be

<MISSING_FIG href=”../books_images/U-IMG-1725951845Capture.JPG”/>

From the scheme mentioned above, the author of the Adhy─Бtma- R─Бm─Бyana does not seem to draw any distinction between the ─Аtman and the S─Бks─▒n, for him both are the same. R─Бma as Par─Бtman is called the S─Бks─▒n ( рдХрд░реНрддреНрддрд╛ рддреНрд╡ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд▓реЛрдХрд╛рдирд╛ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╡рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣ VI 13.4). The commentators explain it as the seer of all (NarottamaтАФ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рдЕрдиреНрдпрд░реНрдпрд╛рдорд┐рддрдпрд╛рд╕рд░реНрд╡рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛ред Gop─Бla CakravartiтАФ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯрд╛ ред рдИрдХреНрд╖рдгрдорд╛рддреНрд░реЗрдгреИрд╡ рдХрд░реНрддреНрддреГрддреНрд╡ рддрд╡реЗрддреНрдпрд░реНрдередрддрдерд╛рдЪ рд╢реНрд░реБрддрд┐’тАУ ’ рддрджреИрдХреНрд╖рдд рдмрд╣реБ рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдореН’ рдЗрддрд┐ред)

The S─Бks─▒n represents the fourth (tur─лya) state which transcends the limiting adjuncts ( рдЬрд╛рдЧреНрд░рддреНрд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдирд╕реБрд╖реБрдкреНрддреНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛ рд╕рд╕реГрддрд┐ рд░реНрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╡рд░реНрддреНрддрддреЗред рддрд╕реНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдг рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖реА рдЪрд┐рдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╕реНрддреНрд╡ рд░рдШреВрддреНрддрдорееII 1 22)

Of the various commentators R─Бmavarman seems to consider the three states of waking, drean and deep sleep (j─Бgrat, svapna and susupti) as appertaining to the different aspects of the S─Бks─▒n. While commenting on the verse just quoted R─Бmavarman says that the three adjunctsтАФ sth┼лla, s┼лksma and h─Бrana refer to the three kinds of S─Бksins. The state of awakening in which the sense-organs are active refers to the Vi┼Ыva-S─Бks─▒n (the witness of the world), the state of dream in which the functions of the sense- organs are absent and the desires are introverted refers to the Ta

ijasa-S─Бksin (the witness of the functions) and the state of deep sleep in which all functions except those relating to the sleep are absentтАФ refers to the Praj├▒─Б-S─Бksin (the witness of the praj├▒─Б or consciousness52)┬╣.

** **The interpretation of R─Бmavarman is not, however, borne out by the texts. Three states described in the text seem to refer to the J─лva and not to the S─Бksin. The texts represent S─Бksin as the state of supreme consciousness without clearly bringing out its relation with the J─лva. The texts define hum as рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рди-рд╡рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ (VI.13.4),

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

  1. рддрддреНрд░рд╕реНрдереВрд▓рд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдореЛрдкрд╛рдзрд┐рднреНрдпрд╛ рдХрд╛рд░рдгреЛрдкрд╛рдзреЗ рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреА рднреЗрджрдХрдорд╛рд╣тАФрдЬрд╛рдЧреНрд░рджрд┐рддрд┐ред рдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╛рджрд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдорддреА рдЬрд╛рдЧреНрд░рджрд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╢реНрд╡рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреАред рдЗрдиреНрджреНрд░рд┐рдпрд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡рдХрд╛рд▓рд┐рдХреА рдЕрдиреНрдд рдХрд░рдгрд╡рд╛рд╕рдирд╛рдирд┐рдорд┐рддреНрддрд╛рд░реНрдереЛрдкрд▓рдореНрднрд░реВрдкрддреИрдЬрд╕рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреА рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдирд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛редрдкреНрд░рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреАрдирд┐рджреНрд░рд╛рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрддрд┐рд░рд┐рдХреНрддрд╕рд░реНрд╡рд╡реГрддреНрддреНрдпрднрд╛рд╡рд░реВрдкрд╛ рд╕реБрд╖реБрдкреНрддрд╛рд╡рд╕реНрдерд╛ред [Com. on II. 1. 22]

рдЪрд┐рдиреНрдорд╛рддреНрд░рдГ(II. 1.22), рд╕рддреНрдпрдкреНрд░рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рдирд╡рд┐рдЧреНрд░рд╣рдГ(II. 7.97) etc and take him to be identical with the Brahman.

But the earlier Advaita system represents S─Бksin as not free from the limiting adjuncts. It is only in the later Advaita texts that S─Бksin is defined in various other ways. Vidy─Бiaс╣Зya defines it as “the unchanging consciousness, which is the substratum of the phenomena of gross and subtle bodies observing the effects without being affected by them in any way53**┬╣тАЭ**In the Tattvaprad─лpik─Б, a work of about the beginning of the 17th Century, the S─Бks─▒n is defined as the pure Brahman, which is the universal self of all creatures and which being the substratum of each individual soul seems to be as many as the j─лva.It is the Absolute devoid of qualities as such it cannot be identified with the J─лva According to the Kaumud─л, a work which was probably composed shortly before the 16th Century, the S─Бksin is a special form of ─к┼Ыvara,

whereas some others maintain that the Jva when conditioned by the Avidy─Б

is the s

ksinas long as he is simply the looker on and not the doer. According to this definition the Ji

va has two aspects the real (S─Бks─▒n orpassive) and the unreal (Abhiman─▒n oractive53)┬▓

The author of the Adhya

tma-Ramayana, therefore, seems to agree mainly with the definition of Saksin as given by Vidyaranya and the Tattvapradipik─Б, whereas amongst his commentators the views expressed by R─Бmavarman are the same as those of the Kaumudi and other works.

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. The Adhya

tma-R─Бm─Бyana defines the Saksin almost in identical terms “The Saksin is unconditioned and unchanging, the kartitva and j─лvatva cannot be attributed to him "

рдЖрднрд╛рд╕рд╡реБрджреНрдзреЗрдХрд░реНрддреНрддреГрддреНрд╡рдорд╡рд┐рдЪреНрдЫрд┐рдиреНрдиреЗрд╜рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд┐ред
рд╕рд╛рдХреНрд╖рд┐рдгреНрдпрд╛рд░реЛрдкреНрдпрддреЗ рднреНрд░рд╛рдиреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рдЬреАрд╡рддреНрд╡рдЮреНрдЪ рддрдерд╛рд╜рдмреБрдзреИрее [I 1 107]

2. Cf. Radhakrishnan-Indian Philosophy, II p 601-603

VI

The Path of Salvation

As R─Бma is the ─Аtman, the Brahman, the S─Бks─▒n etc, the sole reality, salvation from the grasp of the world of illusion consists in attaining the right knowledge about him. This right knowledge or the Vij├▒─Бna is neither the intellect northe function of the mind because they pertain to the world of illusion. Vij├▒─Бna can be acquired through long devotion (Bhakti) to R─Бma. This Vij├▒─Бna produced by Bhuktialone can lead to salvation.

The author of the Adhy─Бtma-R─Бm─Бyana speaks of this path of devotion leading to salvation in the following termsтАФ

(1) R─Бma (as the par─Бtman) resides in the heart of those who always worship him, of those who have controlled themselves completely and have learnt to consider all beings as equal. He feels happy in residing in the heart of those who worship him day and night after abandoning both Dharma and Adharma. The heart of those who are devoted to him, who repeat his name and are free from desires and the knowledge of duality, is the most suitable
abode of R─Бma. R─Бma resides in the heart of those who are devoid of self-sense (ahamk─Бra), anger and hatred and consider even gold as equal to a piece of stone on earth. The heart of those who have resigned their mind, intellect and action to R─Бma, and are always full of satisfaction, is the most auspicious abode of R─Бma. R─Бma resides in the mind of those who neither hate the enemy no are overjoyed at the sight of friend and worship R─Бma after considering all else as illusory. Besides, those who know that the material body is subject to six kinds of transformations whereas the ─Бtman is free from them, that hunger, thirst, pleasure, pain, etc, are the products of the vital wind and the intellect (pr─Бna-buddhi), those who are free from the effects of the world of transmigration, those who discover R─Бma, the consciousness, the sole reality,

the free being which permeates allтАФ within all, those who have strong faith in R─Бma through constant practice, those who have given themselves up entirely to the worship of R─Бma and have dissipated then sin by repeating the name of R─БmaтАФ are all dear to R─Бma who is present within them along with S─лt─Б54┬╣. [II 6 51тАУ59]

(2) The M─Бy─Б is of two kinds, the Vidy─Б and the Avidy─Б. Those who are on the path of desires are under the influence of Avidy─Бand those who are on the path of renunciation and are well placed in the study of the Ved─Бnta are under the influence of the Vidy─Б.Those who are devoted to R─Бma are given to Vidy─Б and those who are given up to Avidy─Б are always the beings of the world of transmigration. Those who are practised in Vidy─Б are ever free. Those who, in this world, are always devoted to R─Бma and utter the Mantra of R─Бma, attain Vidy─Б but not others. Therefore, those who have devotion to R─Бma are without doubt free but those who are lacking in it do not attain Moksa even in dream. The association of good men is conducive to Moksa. They are good men (S─Бdhu) who have attained the calmness of mind, who are fiee from the world of desires, who have controlled then senses, are devoted to R─Бma, in whom all desires are extinguished and to whom

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. рд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рдирд╛ рд╕рдорджреГрд╖реНрдЯреАрдирд╛рдорджреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рдирд╛рдЮреНрдЪ рдЬрдиреНрддреБрд╖реБред рддреНрд╡рд╛рдореЗрд╡ рднрдЬрддрд╛ рдирд┐рддреНрдп рд╣реГрджрдп рддреЗрд╜рдзрд┐рдордиреНрджрд┐рд░рдореНреерелрезрее

рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдиреН рдкрд░рд┐рддреНрдпрдЬреНрдп рддреНрд╡рд╛рдореЗрд╡ рднрдЬрддреЛрд╜рдирд┐рд╢рдореНред рд╕реАрддрдпрд╛ рд╕рд╣ рддреЗ рд░рд╛рдо рддрд╕реНрдп рд╣реГрдд рдореБрдЦрдордиреНрджрд┐рд░рдореНреерелреирее

рддрдиреНрдордиреНрддреНрд░рдЬрд╛рдкрдХреЛ рдпрд╕реНрддреБ рддреНрд╡рд╛рдореЗрд╡ рд╢рд░рдг рдЧрддред рдирд┐рд░реНрджреНрд╡рдиреНрджреНрд╡реЛрдирд┐рд╕реНрдкреГрд╣рд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдп рд╣реГрджрдп рддреЗ рд╕реБрдордиреНрджрд┐рд░рдореНреерелрейрее

рдирд┐рд░рд╣рджреНрдзрд╛рд░рд┐рдг рд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛ рдпреЗ рд░рд╛рдЧрджреНрджреЗрд╖рд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрд╛ред рд╕рдорд▓реЛрд╖реНрдЯрд╛рд╢реНрдордХрдирдХрд╛рд╕реНрддреЗрд╖рд╛ рддреЗ рд╣реГрджрдп рдЧреГрд╣рдореНреерелрекрее

рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рджрддреНрддрдордиреЛрдмреБрджреНрдзрд┐рд░реНрдпрдВ рд╕рдиреНрддреБрд╖реНрдЯ рд╕рджрд╛ рднрд╡реЗрддреНред рддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рд╕рдиреНрдпрд╕реНрддрдХрд░реНрдорд╛ рдпрд╕реНрддрдиреНрдордирд╕реНрддреЗ рд╢реБрдн рдЧреГрд╣рдореНреерелрелрее

рдпреЛ рди рджреНрд╡реЗрд╖реНрдЯреНрдпрдкреНрд░рд┐рдп рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдп рдкреНрд░рд┐рдп рдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрдп рди рд╣реГрд╖реНрдпрддрд┐ред рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рдорд╛рдпреЗрддрд┐ рдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддреНрдп рддреНрд╡рд╛ рднрдЬреЗрддреНрддрдиреНрдордиреЛ рдЧреГрд╣рдореНреерелремрее

рд╖рдбреНрд╡рд░реНрдЧрд╛рджрд┐рд╡рд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреН рдпреЛ рджреЗрд╣реЗ рдкрд╢реНрдпрддрд┐ рдирд╛рд╜рд╜рддреНрдордирд┐ред рдХреНрд╖реБрддреНрддреГрдЯреНрдореБрдЦрднрд╡ рджреБрдГрдЦ рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпреЛрд░реНрдирд┐рд░реАрдХреНрд╖реНрдпрддреЗред

рд╕рд╕рд╛рд░рдзрд░реНрдореИрд░реНрдирд┐рд░реНрдореБрдХреНрддрд╕реНрддрд╕реНрдп рддреЗ рдорд╛рдирд╕ рдЧреНрдЧреГрд╣рдореНреерелренрее

рдкрд╢реНрдпрдиреНрддрд┐ рдпреЗ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдЧреБрд╣рд╛рд╢рдпрд╕реНрде рддреНрд╡рд╛ рдЪрд┐рджреНрдШрди рд╕рддреНрдпрдордирдиреНрддрдореЗрдХрдореНред
рдЕрд▓реЗрдкрдХ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВрдЧрдд рд╡рд░реЗрдгреНрдп рддреЗрд╖рд╛ рд╣реГрджрдмреНрдЬреЗ рд╕рд╣ рд╕реАрддрдпрд╛ рд╡рд╕реерелреорее

рдирд┐рд░рдиреНрддрд░рд╛рднреНрдпрд╛рд╕рджреГрдвреАрдХреГрддрд╛рддреНрдордирд╛ рддрддреНрдкрд╛рджрд╕реЗрд╡рд╛рдкрд░рд┐рдирд┐рд╖реНрдард┐рддрд╛рдирд╛рдореНред
рддреНрд╡рдиреНрдирд╛рдордХреАрд░реНрддреНрддреНрдпрд╛ рд╣рддрдХрд▓реНрдорд╖рд╛рдгрд╛ рд╕реАрддрд╛рд╕рдореЗрддрд╕реНрдп рдЧреГрд╣ рд╣реГрдж

рдпреЗреерелреорее

A-R-7

the pleasure and pain are of equalvalueтАФ who have resigned all then actions to R─Бma and are fixed in BrahmanтАФ practised in religion and are always satisfied with whatever they get One, who gets the association of good men, feels pleased to hear the story of R─Бma, soon gets devoted to the eternal R─Бma. When this feeling of devotion arises, large and clear vision is obtained and the path of liberation opens up before the devotee. Right devotion in R─Бma is the characteristic of love55┬╣[III 3 30-39]

(3) While R─Бma was questioned by ┼Ъavar─лon the mode of worshipping him, he repliedтАФ the question of sex, caste and ─А┼Ыvama is immaterial in the matter of my worshipтАФ the devotion (Bhakti) alone is important. Those who have no devotion to me cannot see me simply by virtue of then sacrifice, gift, asceticism and the study of the Vedas. Therefore, I should explain to you this method of worship though devotion (Bhakti-s─Бdhanam). The first of this S─Бdhana is the association with good men, the second is the talk about me, the thirdтАФ the singing of my qualities, the fourthтАФ the explanation of my body, the fifthтАФ the worship of the ─Аc─Бvyas with a sincere mind fixed on me and the cultivation of merit, the practice of austerity (Yama-niyama), the sixthтАФ the constant faith in my

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. рд░рд╛рдо рдорд╛рдпрд╛ рджреНрд╡рд┐рдзрд╛ рднрд╛рддрд┐ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╜рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рддреЗ рд╕рджрд╛ред рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрдирд┐рд░рддрд╛ рдЕрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╢рд╡рд░реНрддреНрддрд┐рдиред

рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрдирд┐рд░рддрд╛ рд╡реЗрджрд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рд░реНрдерд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░рдХрд╛реерейрежрее

рддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рдирд┐рд░рддрд╛ рдпреЗ рдЪ рддреЗ рд╡реИ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рдордпрд╛ рд╕реНрдореГрддрд╛ред рдЕрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд╢рдЧрд╛ рдпреЗ рддреБ рдирд┐рддреНрдп рд╕рд╕рд╛рд░рд┐рдгрд╢реНрдЪ рддреЗред

рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд╜рднреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд░рддрд╛ рдпреЗ рддреБ рдирд┐рддреНрдпрдореБрдХреНрддрд╛рд╕реНрдд рдПрд╡ рд╣рд┐реерейрезрее

рд▓реЛрдХреЗ рддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рдирд┐рд░рддрд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдиреНрдордиреНрддреНрд░реЛрдкрд╛рд╕рдХрд╛рд╢реНрдЪрдпреЗредрд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╛рджреБрд░реНрднрд╡реЗрддреН рддреЗрд╖рд╛ рдиреЗрддрд░реЗрд╖рд╛ рдХрджрд╛рдЪрдиреерейреирее

рдЕрддрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕рдореНрдкрдиреНрдирд╛ рдореБрдХреНрддрд╛ рдПрд╡ рди рд╕рд╢рдпред рддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддреНрдпрдореГрддрд╣реАрдирд╛рдирд╛ рдореЛрдХреНрд╖ рд╕реНрд╡рдкреНрдиреЗрд╜рдкрд┐ рдиреЛ рднрд╡реЗрддреерейрейрее

рдХрд┐ рд░рд╛рдо рдмрд╣реБрдиреЛрдХреНрддреЗрди рд╕рд╛рд░ рдХрд┐рдЮреНрдЪрд┐рдж рдмреНрд░рд╡реАрдорд┐ рддреЗред рд╕рд╛рдзреБрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрддрд┐рд░реЗрд╡рд╛рддреНрд░рдореЛрдХреНрд╖рд╣реЗрддреБрд░реБрджрд╛рд╣реГрддреерейрелрее

рд╕рд╛рдзрд╡ рд╕рдордЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╛ рдпреЗ рдирд┐ рд╕реНрдкреГрд╣рд╛ рд╡рд┐рдЧрддреИрд╖рдгрд╛ред рджрд╛рдиреНрддрд╛ рдкреНрд░рд╢рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд╛ рдирд┐рд╡реГрддреНрддрд╛рдЦрд┐рд▓рдХрд╛рдордирд╛ред

рдЗрд╖реНрдЯрдкреНрд░рд╛рдкреНрддрд┐рд╡рд┐рдкрддреНрддреНрдпреЛрд╢реНрдЪ рд╕рдорд╛ рд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╡рд┐рд╡рд░реНрдЬрд┐рддрд╛реерейрелрее

рд╕рдиреНрдиреНрдпрд╕реНрддрд╛рдЦрд┐рд▓рдХрд░реНрдорд╛рдг рд╕рд░реНрд╡рджрд╛ рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдорддрддреНрдкрд░рд╛ред рдпрдорд╛рджрд┐рдЧреБрдгрд╕рдореНрдкрдиреНрдирд╛рдГ рд╕рдиреНрддреБрд╖реНрдЯрд╛ рдпреЗрди рдХреЗрдирдЪрд┐рддреНреерейремрее

рд╕рддреНрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрдореЛ рднрд╡реЗрджреН рдпрд░реНрд╣рд┐рдВрддреНрд╡рддреНрдХрдерд╛рд╢реНрд░рд╡рдгреЗ рд░рддрд┐ред рд╕рдореБрджреЗрддрд┐ рддрддреЛ рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рд░рд╛рдо рд╕рдирд╛рддрдиреЗреерейренрее

рддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд╛рд╡реБрдкрдкрдиреНрдирд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рд╡рд┐рдЬреНрдЮрд╛рди рд╡рд┐рдкреБрд▓ рд╕реНрдлреБрдЯрдореНред рдЙрджреЗрддрд┐ рдореБрдХреНрддрд┐рдорд╛рд░реНрдЧреЛрд╜рдпрдорд╛рджреНрдпрд╢реНрдЪрддреБрд░рд╕реЗрд╡рд┐рддреерейреорее

рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреНрд░рд╛рдШрд╡ рд╕рджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕реНрддреНрд╡рдпрд┐ рдореЗ рдкреНрд░реЗрдорд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛ред рд╕рджрд╛ рднреВрдпрд╛рджреНрдзрд░реЗрд╕рдЩреНрдЧрд╕реНрддреНрд╡рджреНрднрдХреНрддреЗрд╖реБ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖рдд.реерейреорее

worship, the seventhтАФ the uttering of mantras relating to me and the eighth and the ninth consist in paying greater respects to those who are devoted to me, in finding myself present in all beings, in not getting attached to the matters of the external world and in practising self-control. These are the nine kinds of the practice of Bhakti. In all beings, either male or female, either of the higher order or the lower, can arise the Bhakti, characterized by higher love (рдкреНрд░реЗрдорд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛). As soon as the Bhakt arises one can know the secret of me (R─Бma) One who succeeds in attaining this know ledge gets liberated even in this life. Therefore, Bhakti is the most certain cause of Moksa. If one succeeds in practising the first S─Бdhana (of the nine S─Бdhanas), the success in others comes gradually and naturally. The Bhakti is, therefore, the same as the Mukti. As you come with a spirit of devotion towards me, you have been able to see me and thus attain the spiritual liberation (Mukti56)┬╣[III. 10 20-29]

(4) No differentiation should be made between the J─лva and the Parm─Бtman ie, the individual self and the universal one.

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. рдкреБрд╕реНрддреНрд╡реЗрд╕реНрддреНрд░реАрддреНрд╡реЗ рд╡рд┐рд╢реЗрд╖реЛ рд╡рд╛ рдЬрд╛рддрд┐рдирд╛рдорд╛рд╢реНрд░рдорд╛рджрдпред
рди рдХрд╛рд░рдг рдорджреНрднрдЬрдиреЗ рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реЗрд╡ рд╣рд┐ рдХрд╛рд░рдгрдореНреереирежрее

рдпрдЬреНрдЮрджрд╛рдирддрдкреЛрднрд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛ рд╡реЗрджрд╛рдзреНрдпрдпрдирдХрд░реНрдорднрд┐рдГред
рдиреИрд╡ рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯреБрдорд╣ рд╢рдХреНрдпреЛ рдорджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╡рд┐рдореБрдЦреИ рд╕рджрд╛ред

рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджреНрднрд╛рдорд┐рдирд┐ рд╕рдХреНрд╖реЗрдкрд╛рджреНрд╡рдХреНрд╖реНрдпреЗрд╜рд╣ рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕рд╛рдзрдирдореНреереирезрее

рд╕рддрд╛ рд╕рд░рддрд┐рд░реЗрд╡рд╛рддреНрд░ рд╕рд╛рдзрди рдкреНрд░рдердо рд╕реНрдореГрддрдореНред
рджреНрд╡рд┐рддреАрдп рдорддреНрдХрдерд╛рд▓рд╛рдкрд╕реНрддреГрддреАрдп рдорджреНрдЧреБрдгреЗрд░рдгрдореНреереиреирее

рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддреГрддреНрд╡ рдорджреНрд╡рдЪрд╕рд╛ рдЪрддреБрд░реНрде рд╕рд╛рдзрди рднрд╡реЗрддред
рдЖрдЪрд╛рд░реНрдпреЛрдкрд╛рд╕рдирдВ рднрджреНрд░реЗ рдорджреНрдмреБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд╛рд╜рдорд╛рдпрдпрд╛ рд╕рджрд╛ред

рдкрдЮреНрдЪрдо рдкреБрдгреНрдпрд╢реАрд▓рддреНрд╡ рдпрдорд╛рджрд┐ рдирд┐рдпрдорд╛рджрд┐ рдЪреереирейрее

рдирд┐рд╖реНрдард╛ рдорддрдкреВрдЬрдиреЗ рдирд┐рддреНрдп рд╖рд╖реНрда рд╕рд╛рдзрдирдореАрд░рд┐рддрдореНред
рдордо рдордиреНрддреНрд░реЛрдкрд╛рд╕рдХрддреНрд╡ рд╕рд╛рдЩреНрдЧрд╕рдкреНрддрдордореБрдЪреНрдпрддреЗреереирекрее

рдорджреНрднрдХреНрддреЗрд╖реНрд╡рдзрд┐рдХрд╛ рдкреВрдЬрд╛ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рднреВрддреЗрд╖реБ рдордиреНрдорддрд┐ред
рдмрд╛рд╣реНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереЗрд╖реБ рд╡рд┐рд░рд╛рдЧрд┐рддреНрд╡ рд╢рдорд╛рджрд┐рд╕рд╣рд┐рдд рддрдерд╛ред

рдЕрд╖реНрдЯрдо рдирд╡рдо рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░реЛ рдордо рднрд╛рдорд┐рдирд┐реереирелрее

рдПрд╡ рдирд╡рд╡рд┐рдзрд╛ рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕рд╛рдзрди рдпрд╕реНрдп рдХрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╛ред
рд╕реНрддреНрд░рд┐рдпреЛ рд╡рд╛ рдкреБрд░реБрд╖рд╕реНрдпрд╛рдкрд┐ рддрд┐рд░реНрдпреНрдпрдЧреНрдпреЛрдирд┐рдЧрддрд╕реНрдп рд╡рд╛ред

рднрдХреНрддрд┐ рд╕рдЮреНрдЬрд╛рдпрддреЗ рдкреНрд░реЗрдорд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрд╛ рд╢реБрднрд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгреЗреереиремрее

рднрдХреНрддреМ рд╕рдЮреНрдЬрд╛рддрдорд╛рддреНрд░рд╛рдпрд╛рдВ рдорддреНрддрддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рдиреБрднрд╡рд╕реНрддрдерд╛ред
рдордорд╛рдиреБрднрд╡рд╕рд┐рджреНрдзрд╕реНрдп рдореБрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕реНрддрддреНрд░реИрд╡ рдЬрдиреНрдордирд┐рее

рд╕реНрдпрд╛рддреНрддрд╕реНрдорд╛рддреН рдХрд╛рд░рдг рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реНрдореЛрдХреНрд╖рд╕реНрдпреЗрддрд┐ рд╕реБрдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддрдореНреереиренрее

рдкреНрд░рдердо рд╕рд╛рдзрди рдпрд╕реНрдп рднрд╡реЗрддреН рддрд╕реНрдп рдХреНрд░рдореЗрдг рддреБред
рднрд╡реЗрддреН рд╕рд░реНрд╡рдВ рддрддреЛ рднрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реНрдореБрдХреНрддрд┐рд░реЗрд╡ рд╕реБрдирд┐рд╢реНрдЪрд┐рддрдореНреереиреорее

рдпрд╕реНрдорд╛рдиреНрдорджреНрднрдХреНрддрд┐рдпреБрдХреНрддрд╛ рддреНрд╡ рддрддреЛрд╜рд╣ рддреНрд╡рд╛рдореБрдкрд╕реНрдерд┐рддред
рдЗрддреЛ рдорджреНрджрд░реНрд╢рдирд╛рдиреНрдореБрдХреНрддрд┐рд╕реНрддрд╡ рдирд╛рд╕реНрддреНрдпрддреНрд░рд╕рдВрд╢рдпрдГреереиреорее

One should not have any attachment to the material body. Hatred should be abandoned, Abuse of others should be patiently brooked, one should be straight in all dealings and devoted to a good guruin mind, speech and body. Purity, both external and internal, steadfastness in religious acts, severity in regard to thought, speech and act, want of attachment to objects, want of self-sense (ahamk─Бra), the realisation of the truth about birth, old age etc, want of attachment and affection for wife and children, calmness of mind in regard to good and evil, spiritual devotion to R─Бma, frequentation of solitary places, dissociation with ordinary people of the world, enthusiasm in acquiring a knowledge of the ─Бtman and research after the true sense of the Ved─БntaтАФ all these produce (right) knowledge. R─Бma, the conscious illumined self, which is ever pure, is different from the intellect, the vital strength, mind, body, self-sense etc (рдмреБрджреНрд╡рдкреНрд░рд╛рдгрдордиреЛрджреЗрд╣рд╛рд╣рдбреНрдХреГрддрд┐рднреНрдпреЛ рд╡рд┐рд▓рдХреНрд╖рдгрдГ). That kind of knowledge, which enables one to know him is the vij├▒─Бna. Vij├▒─Бna leads to the direct perception of the ─Бtman57┬╣. As soon as the knowledge of unity (between the J─лva and the ─Бtman) is attained, one realises at once that the sense of differentiation is due to avidy─Б.He at once merges into the Param─Бtman along with his gross and subtle adjuncts (рдХрд╛рд░реНрдпрдХрд╛рд░рдгреИ). Such a state is called the Mukti o spiritual liberation Such is the nature of moksa, j├▒─Бna, vij├▒─Бna and vair─Бgya.

Bhakti or devotion to R─Бma alone leads to moksa. Bhakti arises by associating with those who are devoted to R─Бma and observing fast on the 11th day of each fortnight and on other days sacred to R─Бma. It can be acquired also by listening always to the stories of R─Бma, by worshipping R─Бma and repeating his name. Those who attain bhakt╔й in this way acquie knowledgeтАФ knowledge that leads to spiritual liberation, the spirit of renunciation and last of all, the mukti without any delay58^(2)[III 4 20-48]

(5) After being consecrated according to rules laid down in the Grhyu aphorisms relating to one’s own religious order (─Б┼Ыrama), one should get the mantra fiom a good guru in the right spirit of devotion and should worship R─Бma in the way indicated by him. R─Бma should be worshipped either within the heart, or within the fire, image, the sun or the ┼Ы─Бligr─Бma stone. The devotee should bathe himself early in the morning in order to purify his body and then perform his sandhy─Бrites after making his body with clay by uttering the mantras of the Vedas and the Tantras. Then he should enter into a proposition (samkalpa) for success and worship the guru in a devoted spirit. After washing the (┼Ы─Бl─▒gr─Бma) ┼Ыil─Б with water and cleansing the image, one should worship R─Бma in them with fragrant flowers suitable for the woiship of R─Бma, Such worship leads to (spiritual) success In order to worship R─Бma one should be sincere at heart and devoted to him. The images ought to be decorated with ornaments. While woishipping R─Бma in the fire one should offer butter, but in woishipping R─Бma in the sun an altarshould be used Even water offered in faith is enough to please R─Бma, in that case expensive offerings become superfluous. After collecting the things necessary for the worship one should prepare a seat either with silk (cela) on the deer skin (ajina) orku┼Ыa grass. On being seated thereon in front of the god with a pure mind, one should practise p─Бn─Бy─Бma with mantras (рддрддреЛ рдиреНрдпрд╛рд╕ рдкреНрд░рдХреБрд░реНрд╡реАрдд рдорд╛рддреГрдХрд╛рдмрд╣рд┐рд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд░рдореН) Then one should performтАФ (I) the uttering of the 24 names of R─Бma beginning with Ke┼Ыava, (II) the tattvany─Бsa59.”), (III) (R─Бma)-m┼лrti-pa├▒jarany─Бsa, (IV) mantrany─Бsa.

The sacred pot filled with water should be placed on the left, the offerings of flower and other things should be made on the right and the four pots for arghya, p─Бdya, madhuparka and ─Бcamana should be placed in the middle. One should meditate on that form of supreme consciousness which is called J─лva within the

heart as enveloping oneself. That form of consciousness also should be invoked in the images for worship. It should be woishipped with p─Бdya, arghya, ─Бcamana, cloth etc, according to one’s own means with a sincere heart, If the means permit, Karp┼лra, Kunkuma, Aguru, Candana, fragrant flowers etc, should be used in the Worship. The worship of the ten coverings as prescrbed by the ─Аgama [comm Agastyasamhit─Б] should be performed with various thingsтАФ

Th┼лpa, na

rredya etc, and in sincere faith. The Homa should be carefully performed in a Kundu dug according to the prescription of Agastya [comm cf the chapter on Homakunda ─▒n the Agastyasamhit─Б] Oblations are to be offered to the fire either with the original mantra60┬╣ or with the Purusas┼лkta [of the Rgveda] At the time of the Homa one should meditate on the form [of R─Бma] as shining like pure gold and adorned with godly dress and ornaments in the midst of the [sacrificial] fire. After dedicating offerings to the attendants [of R─Бma] and thus completing the sacrifice, one should meditate on R─Бma and perform the Japa (repetition of his name). Then after offering scented betel to R─Бma and entertaining him with dancing, singing and the recital of his praiseworthy deeds, one should bow unto R─Бma and play for salvation from the world of transmigration. Thus only success may be attained [IV 4 10-34]

(6) V─Бlmiki speaks on the means of salvationтАФ the body is the great house of the ─Аtman which isconsciousness and formless Self-sense (Ahamk─Бra) is the minister to the ─Аtman and is Created by the ─Аtman. The self-sense attributes its attachment for the material body to the conscious ─Аtman and establishes (an apparent) connexion of its own acts with the ─Аtman. The beings with body under the influence of the creative desires of the self-sense hanker after the family home etc, and thus bring about sufferings

тАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФтАФ

I. The m┼лlamantra is explained in the commentary of R─Бmavarman as go рдореВрд▓рдордиреНрддреНрд░реЗрдгрд╛рдЧрдордХреНрддреЗрди, it seems to mean the b─лja-mantra of the sacrificer. In case the sacrificer has no b─лja-mantra he should use the purusa-s┼лkta as the mantra.

for themselves. The self-sense brings into existence three kinds of bodiesтАФ low, high and middle (рдЕрдзрдореЛрддреНрддрдордорд╡реНрдпрдорд╛) relating to the three gunasтАФ tamas, sattva and rajas, which serve as the main cause of the preservation of the world. The creative desire under the influence of tamas leads to sinful acts and a consequent rebirth amongst the baser beings. The creative desire under the influence of sattra leads to higher knowledge and consequently to the bliss of salvation without delay. The creative desire under the influence of rajas leads to the worldly ways and brings about attachment for wife, childienetc.
